title: Building High-Performance Teams
description: Transform underperforming teams into high-performance teams by building trust, psychological safety, clear goals, shared accountability, and continuous improvement.
objectives: Apply team performance assessment criteria (velocity, quality, collaboration, morale) to identify performance gaps
Recognize characteristics of high-performance teams (trust, shared accountability, clear goals, psychological safety, continuous improvement)
Build psychological safety (team members feel safe to take risks, voice concerns, admit mistakes without fear of punishment)
Transform underperforming teams through trust-building exercises, role clarity, removing impediments, and celebrating wins
Distinguish co-located vs distributed team challenges and apply appropriate collaboration strategies (synchronous pairing, asynchronous documentation)
Understand that high performance is SUSTAINED through continuous improvement, not a one-time achievement

screens.headline: Underperforming team: 30% below velocity, 15% defect rate, 3.2/10 morale. Carlos: 'Fire them!' Alex: 'Transform them.' Can team dynamics unlock high performance?

dialogue.text: High-performance teams aren't born—they're built. TRUST, clear GOALS, psychological SAFETY, shared ACCOUNTABILITY, continuous IMPROVEMENT. Mexico team has none of these. Fix the dynamics, and performance follows.

screens.learningHook: Your job: Build psychological safety, establish trust, set clear goals, create shared accountability, and enable continuous improvement to transform Mexico City team from underperforming to high-performing.

screens.title: Team Transformation Decisions
screens.instructions: Guide the Mexico City team through transformation by making the right interventions for each challenge.

scenarios.title: Building Psychological Safety - Fear of Asking Questions
scenarios.description: Lucia Martinez (Junior Chef) makes 3 mistakes in one shift (wrong portions, incorrect temperature, missing labels). Maria (Kitchen Lead) asks: 'Why didn't you ask for help?' Lucia: 'I didn't want to look incompetent. Roberto got angry last week when someone asked a stupid question.' Team culture: Fear of asking questions → mistakes → blame → more fear.
observableBehaviors: Team members afraid to ask questions
Mistakes due to lack of clarification

quotes.text: I didn't want to look incompetent. Roberto got angry last week when someone asked a 'stupid question.'
Why didn't you ask for help before making these mistakes?

questions.question: What should Alex do to build psychological safety?

options.text: Discipline Roberto for discouraging questions
Create 'no stupid questions' policy document
Model vulnerability (Alex shares own mistakes), celebrate questions asked, implement 'question of the week' award
Remove Lucia from team (performance issue)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Psychological safety requires leaders MODEL vulnerability (Alex shares mistakes), CELEBRATE questions (not punish), REWARD learning. After Alex implemented 'question of week' award, Lucia asked questions freely, mistakes dropped 3/shift to 0.5/shift. Dr. Foster: 'Safety is built from top down—leaders set the tone.'
feedback.incorrect: Punitive approaches or policies alone don't build psychological safety. Leaders must MODEL vulnerability, CELEBRATE questions, and REWARD learning behaviors to create a safe environment.

scenarios.title: Building Trust - Blame Culture to Shared Accountability
scenarios.description: Defect found: 15% of meals have incorrect portions. Roberto (Senior Chef): 'QA didn't catch it—that's Diego's fault.' Diego (QA Lead): 'Kitchen didn't follow portioning guide—that's Roberto's fault.' Team blames EACH OTHER instead of solving PROBLEM together. Maria to Alex: 'No one takes ownership. Everyone points fingers.'

quotes.text: QA didn't catch it—that's Diego's fault.
Kitchen didn't follow portioning guide—that's Roberto's fault.
No one takes ownership. Everyone points fingers.

questions.question: How should Alex transform blame culture into shared accountability?

options.text: Identify who's at fault and discipline them
Facilitate joint problem-solving session (5 Whys root cause), create team ownership ('We all own quality')
Separate teams (Kitchen and QA don't interact)
Fire both Roberto and Diego (blame culture leaders)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Blame culture to Shared accountability through joint 5 Whys (Roberto + Diego discover systemic issue—uncalibrated scales, not individual fault), team ownership ('We ALL own quality'), celebrate team wins. Roberto changed from 'Your fault' to 'We solve it together.' Trust increases when blame stops.
feedback.incorrect: Punitive approaches or separation reinforce blame culture. Transform by facilitating joint root cause analysis to reveal systemic issues, establishing team ownership, and celebrating collective wins.

scenarios.title: Setting Clear Goals - Team Doesn't Know What Success Looks Like
scenarios.description: Alex asks Maria's team: 'What's your goal for this sprint?' Responses vary: Roberto: 'Cook good food' / Lucia: 'Don't make mistakes' / Diego: 'Catch defects before shipping' / Maria: 'I thought our goal was 300 meals/day?' No shared understanding of success. Team works hard but in different directions.

quotes.text: I thought our goal was 300 meals/day?

questions.question: How should Alex establish clear goals?

options.text: Tell team the goal and expect compliance
Facilitate goal-setting session (SMART goals), create visible dashboard, align individual contributions to team goal
Let team define own goals independently
Remove goals to reduce pressure

feedback.correct: Perfect! Clear goals = SMART (300 meals/day, <2% defects by sprint end), VISIBLE (kitchen dashboard shows daily progress), ALIGNED (individual contributions to team goal). Team works toward SAME goal, velocity increased 21 to 32 story points. Dr. Foster: 'No shared goal = team works hard in different directions.'
feedback.incorrect: Top-down mandates lack buy-in, independent goal-setting risks misalignment. Facilitate SMART goal-setting with the team, make progress visible, and align individual contributions to shared goals.

scenarios.title: Distributed Team Collaboration - SF HQ + Mexico City
scenarios.description: Mexico City team (5 people) works separately from SF HQ team (3 people). Time zone: 1-hour difference (manageable). Problem: NO knowledge sharing. SF team solved menu optimization problem (saved 15 min/shift), but Mexico doesn't know. Mexico solved portioning issue (calibrated scales), but SF doesn't know. Silos prevent learning.

quotes.text: Mexico solved a portioning issue that SF is still struggling with. They don't even know about each other's wins.

questions.question: How should Alex enable collaboration across locations?

options.text: Require daily video calls (all 8 people)
Implement asynchronous knowledge sharing (Slack channel for wins/lessons) + bi-weekly sync (30 min) for deep dives
Consolidate teams in one location
Accept silos (teams work independently)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Distributed teams need HYBRID: Async knowledge sharing (Slack 'Wins & Lessons' channel) respects time zones + documents learning, Bi-weekly sync (30 min) for deep dives. SF adopted Mexico's scale calibration, Mexico adopted SF's menu optimization. Collaboration drives performance across locations.
feedback.incorrect: Daily calls are time-consuming for small time differences, consolidation is costly, and accepting silos loses learning opportunities. Use hybrid approach: async primary (respects time zones) + strategic sync sessions.

characteristics.name: TRUST
characteristics.definition: Team members rely on each other, assume positive intent, vulnerability-based trust
characteristics.indicator: Team shares mistakes openly, asks for help, no finger-pointing
characteristics.building: Model vulnerability (leader shares mistakes first), celebrate risk-taking, transparency

characteristics.name: CLEAR GOALS
characteristics.definition: Shared understanding of what success looks like (SMART goals)
characteristics.indicator: Team can articulate goal without PM prompting, progress visible
characteristics.building: Facilitate goal-setting (involve team), create visible dashboard, align individual contributions

characteristics.name: PSYCHOLOGICAL SAFETY
characteristics.definition: Team feels safe to take risks, voice concerns, admit mistakes without fear
characteristics.indicator: Questions asked freely, disagreements expressed constructively, no punishment for mistakes
characteristics.building: Leaders model openness, celebrate questions, reward learning behaviors

characteristics.name: SHARED ACCOUNTABILITY
characteristics.definition: Team collectively owns outcomes, not individuals blamed
characteristics.indicator: 'We' language (vs 'I/they'), joint problem-solving, celebrate team wins
characteristics.building: Facilitate root cause analysis together, establish team ownership, avoid individual blame

characteristics.name: CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT
characteristics.definition: Regular reflection, feedback loops, implemented learnings
characteristics.indicator: Retrospectives every sprint, action items tracked, measurable improvement
characteristics.building: Retrospectives (Start-Stop-Continue), experiment with changes, track metrics

blocks.title: Psychological Safety - Foundation of High Performance

content.keyFinding: Google's Project Aristotle finding: Psychological safety is THE #1 factor for high-performance teams (more important than individual talent).

points: Team members feel safe to take interpersonal risks
Can ask questions without fear of looking incompetent

howToBuild: Leader models vulnerability: Share own mistakes ('I forgot stakeholder in meeting—learned to check my list')
Celebrate questions: 'Great question!' (not 'You should know this')
Respond to mistakes with curiosity, not blame: 'What can we learn?' (not 'Who messed up?')
Reward speaking up: 'Thank you for raising this concern'

blocks.title: Trust Building - From Blame to Shared Ownership

sharedAccountabilityIndicators: 'We' language ('We missed the deadline,' not 'Roberto missed it')
Joint problem-solving (5 Whys root cause analysis together)
transformationApproach: Facilitate joint problem-solving: Root cause analysis TOGETHER (reveals systemic issues, not individual faults)
Establish team ownership: 'We ALL own quality/velocity/morale'
Celebrate team wins: Defect rate drops 15% to 2% = team celebration
Model 'we' language: PM says 'We missed target' (not 'You missed target')

content.colocatedTeams: Easy synchronous collaboration (in-person meetings, whiteboard sessions, coffee chats)

methods: Recorded video demos (Mexico shows scale calibration process)
Rotate meeting times (share time zone burden)
Virtual pairing sessions (2 people collaborate on problem)

screens.title: Toronto Team Performance Assessment
screens.context: Toronto expansion team (6 members) completed 3 sprints. Performance metrics: Velocity: 28/30 story points (93% of target), Quality: 3% defect rate (target: <2%), Morale: Team satisfaction 7.5/10, Collaboration: Team survey shows 2 concerns: (1) 'I don't feel safe admitting mistakes' (psychological safety gap), (2) 'I don't know what others are working on' (visibility gap)

questions.question: First priority action to improve Toronto team to high-performance level:

options.text: Fire underperforming team members
Build psychological safety: Alex models vulnerability, celebrates mistakes as learning, implements 'mistake of sprint' award
Increase meeting frequency to improve communication
Set stricter quality standards and penalties

feedback.correct: Excellent! Building psychological safety addresses the root cause. When team feels safe admitting mistakes, quality improves (catches issues earlier), morale increases.
feedback.incorrect: The team survey identified psychological safety as a gap. Address this by having leaders model vulnerability and celebrate learning from mistakes.

questions.question: Second priority action to improve Toronto team:

options.text: Create detailed project documentation
Increase visibility: Create visible dashboard, daily async standup (Slack), weekly team demo
Assign team members to individual projects to reduce dependencies
Hire additional team members

feedback.correct: Perfect! Increasing visibility addresses the collaboration gap. When team knows what others are working on, collaboration increases and dependencies are identified earlier.
feedback.incorrect: The team survey identified visibility as a gap ('I don't know what others are working on'). Address this with visible dashboards and regular sharing.

screens.title: Building High-Performance Teams
screens.summary: High-performance teams share 5 characteristics: TRUST (vulnerability-based), clear GOALS (SMART, visible, aligned), psychological SAFETY (safe to take risks, admit mistakes), shared ACCOUNTABILITY (team ownership, no blame), continuous IMPROVEMENT (retrospectives, feedback loops). Transform underperforming teams by building these dynamics, not replacing people.
takeaways: 5 Characteristics: Trust, Clear Goals, Psychological Safety, Shared Accountability, Continuous Improvement
Psychological safety = #1 factor (Google Project Aristotle)—safe to ask questions, admit mistakes, voice concerns
Build trust through joint problem-solving, team ownership, celebrate team wins (not individuals)
Clear goals = SMART, visible dashboard, aligned individual contributions
Distributed teams: Async primary (Slack, docs, recorded demos) + Sync strategic (bi-weekly calls, virtual pairing)
High performance is SUSTAINED through continuous improvement (retrospectives, experiments, metrics)

characterClosing.text: I wanted to fire the team. You showed me the problem was dynamics, not people. Mexico team went from 3.2/10 morale to 8.5/10 by building trust and safety. That's real transformation.
